label: Letter from Angelina Grimke Weld directed to "Sisters," referencing the death of sister Sarah M. Grimke, December 25, 1873
description: A letter from Angelina Grimke Weld to her sisters relating her sorrow after the death of her sister, Sarah Weld Grimke, and discusses some of the funeral arrangements prepared.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: A letter from Angelina Grimke Weld to her sisters relating her sorrow after the death of her sister, Sarah Weld Grimke, and discusses some of the funeral arrangements prepared.

metadata.label: Access Note
metadata.value: For more information and reuse requirements contact Special Collections at Addlestone Library, College of Charleston, Charleston, SC, 29424.

metadata.label: Digitization Specifications
metadata.value: 600 dpi, 24-bit depth, color, Epson Expression 10000XL, Archival masters are tiffs.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
Decr 25

My Dear Sisters-
The letters I wrote you last
week must have prepared for the [illegible]
of my beloved Sister- to me, from my child-
hood up she had been a Mother Sister, friend
counsellor and companion- every thing that a
woman of a pure, loving heart could be
to another- but she is gone and I shall never
look upon her like again again- she had
borne all my burdens in life I shared all
my joys generously sympathizing with
me in all the deep sorrows and joys of life-
but I cannot help rejoicing with her
for I know it is her everlasting gain and that
she will never suffer any more pain for her
agonies are past- As soon as I realized
that in her feeble state, she had taken a dread-
ful cold, I could not hope that even her strong
constitution could ever master it, and therefore
could not expect to see her recover, but every
thing was done to save her life that could be
done, for dear Stuart did not feel so- he hop'd 
on and worked to the very last and even when she
was seized with her last attack of shortness of
breath last tuesday afternoon he was prepar-
ing to go to Boston to try to get Dr. Munroe 

[End page 1]

to come out and see her, but as he could not
bear to leave her whilst suffering, he staid
supposing it would pass off- but it never
did until in about 3 hours she was re
leased by the hand of death and went up
to join the Church of the first born- For
2 hours she suffered great agony for want of
breath- but this gradually subsided and we
hardly knew when she breathed her last-

Theodore, myself and Stuart were with her and her
faithful nurse but we were all powerless
to relieve the battle for breath the poor soul
had to fight alone- We had mutually
[illegible] each other to perform the last offic-
es, and I did putting on my own clothes on
her and knowing that she had a great many
friends round Boston we have put the fu-
neral off until Saturday- This is the sad-
dest Christams I ever spent she begged to
buried in a wooden coffin at no lavish ex-
pense but in great simplicity and at no [illegible]
necessary expense- the poor need such
a testimony- funerals are very expensive here
We shall purchase a lot in Mt. Hope Ce-
metery about 3 miles off- I can write
no more now but will next week

Affy AGW

[End page 2]
